metadata.product: COSORI Pro II Air Fryer Oven Combo, 5.8QT

transcript.speaker: **Customer Interview
transcript.text: COSORI Pro II Air Fryer Oven Combo**

transcript.speaker: **Interviewer
transcript.text: ** Jessica (Corporate Representative)

transcript.speaker: **Interviewee
transcript.text: ** Kevin (Customer) ---

transcript.speaker: **Jessica
transcript.text: ** Hi Kevin, my name is Jessica, and I’m calling from COSORI. Thank you so much for taking the time to speak with me today. We really appreciate you leaving such a thoughtful and detailed review for your Pro II Air Fryer Oven Combo. We value all our customer feedback, and your insights are incredibly helpful for us to continue improving our products.

transcript.speaker: **Kevin
transcript.text: ** Oh, no problem, Jessica. Yeah, I remember writing that. You know, it’s a good product overall, so I didn’t mind sharing my thoughts. Glad it’s helpful.

transcript.speaker: **Jessica
transcript.text: ** It absolutely is. So, to start, could you tell me a little bit more about what initially prompted you to look for an air fryer? What was the main problem you were trying to solve in your kitchen?

transcript.speaker: **Kevin
transcript.text: ** Hmm, well, it was mostly about, uh, trying to make dinner quicker and healthier for the family. You know, two adults, two school-aged kids, everyone’s got activities, work, it gets pretty hectic by the time evening rolls around. We were using the oven a lot for things like fries or chicken nuggets, but it just felt… slow, and then the deep fryer was, well, deep-frying, which we wanted to cut down on. So, an air fryer seemed like a good middle ground – quick, but also healthier.

transcript.speaker: **Jessica
transcript.text: ** That makes perfect sense. So, with that in mind, what specifically drew you to the COSORI Pro II model over others you might have seen on the market? Were there any particular features or price points that stood out?

transcript.speaker: **Kevin
transcript.text: ** Yeah, good question. I remember doing a fair bit of research online, reading reviews, comparing brands. As a buyer, you know, I always look for that sweet spot of value and performance. The COSORI Pro II, uh, it seemed to have a good reputation for cooking performance, which was key, and the capacity, 5.8 quarts, was advertised as being suitable for a family. Price-wise, it was competitive, not the cheapest, but not the most expensive either. It felt like a solid investment without breaking the bank, especially for something we hoped to use almost daily.

transcript.speaker: **Jessica
transcript.text: ** Understood. And you mentioned that it's "definitely earned its spot on your countertop." Could you elaborate on what aspects really made it indispensable for your family's routine? What kinds of foods are you finding yourselves making most often, and how has that changed things?

transcript.speaker: **Kevin
transcript.text: ** Oh, absolutely. I mean, the kids, they love anything crispy – chicken nuggets, fish sticks, fries. Before, it was either greasy deep-fried stuff or kind of sad, soggy oven-baked versions. With the COSORI, they come out *perfectly* golden and crisp, every time. It’s like, restaurant quality without the… well, the restaurant. And way less oil, which is a huge plus for us parents. But honestly, the biggest game-changer for me personally has been reheating pizza. I swear, it’s like magic. It brings it back to life, that fresh-out-of-the-box crispness. No more microwave rubbery crust.

transcript.speaker: **Jessica
transcript.text: ** *[Chuckles]* Yes, the pizza reheating is a fan favorite! It sounds like the performance really lived up to your expectations for those crispy foods. You also mentioned trying roasted salmon and cookies. How did those turn out, and are they something you make regularly in the air fryer?

transcript.speaker: **Kevin
transcript.text: ** The salmon was actually surprisingly good, very flaky and moist, which I didn't quite expect from an air fryer. I wouldn't say we make it *regularly* in there, probably more of a weekend thing, but it’s nice to know it can handle more delicate stuff. Cookies were good too, nice crust. It’s definitely versatile. But our go-to, daily use cases are definitely the kid-friendly stuff and, like I said, pizza. It’s a workhorse for those quick meals.

transcript.speaker: **Jessica
transcript.text: ** That’s great to hear. Now, in your review, you also mentioned a few "minor imperfections" or "quibbles." I'd like to dive into those a bit, if you don't mind, so we can understand them better. You talked about the 5.8-quart capacity being "just enough" and sometimes requiring two batches for fries. Could you tell me how frequently that happens, and what kind of impact it has on your meal prep?

transcript.speaker: **Kevin
transcript.text: ** Yeah, sure. Uh, it happens pretty often, especially with fries or, say, if I'm doing a larger batch of chicken wings. For a family of four, if we're doing a main like chicken thighs, it's fine. But for sides that need to be spread out for proper crisping, like fries, I almost always have to do two batches. It’s not a deal-breaker, but it definitely adds, oh, I don’t know, an extra 10 to 15 minutes to dinner prep. When you're trying to get food on the table after a long day, those extra minutes can sometimes feel longer, you know? It's just a bit of a juggle, having to pull one batch out, keep it warm, then put the next batch in.

transcript.speaker: **Jessica
transcript.text: ** I can definitely see how that would be a frustration when you're trying to get a family meal ready efficiently. It’s a common point of feedback we hear for air fryers in general. Moving on to another point, you mentioned that cleaning around the edges of the crisper plate can be "fiddly" and that food bits tend to get caught in the crevices. Could you describe your cleaning process for it and what makes it particularly challenging?

transcript.speaker: **Kevin
transcript.text: ** Oh, man, yeah, the cleaning. So, the non-stick coating on the main basket is fantastic, wipes clean no problem. But the crisper plate, that slotted insert? Bits of food, especially if something gets a little sticky or burned on, they just get lodged in those little grooves and around the edges. I usually soak it, then try to get in there with a brush, but even then, sometimes it takes a bit of elbow grease. It's not impossible, just more time-consuming than it feels like it should be. It's a small thing, but it does sometimes make me think twice about making certain super-sticky foods, just knowing the cleanup challenge.

transcript.speaker: **Jessica
transcript.text: ** That's really helpful feedback. So, the main basket is great, but the crisper plate requires more dedicated effort due to its design. And thinking about the overall design, you also noted that the plastic casing attracts fingerprints easily, and the cord length is a bit short. How significant are these aspects for you in terms of your overall satisfaction or daily use?

transcript.speaker: **Kevin
transcript.text: ** The fingerprints are just a minor annoyance, really. I just find myself wiping it down more often than I'd like to keep it looking tidy on the counter. It's not a performance issue, just aesthetic. The cord length, though, that’s a bit more impactful. My kitchen layout, um, it just limits where I can place it. I have a preferred spot, but the cord doesn't quite reach the outlet there comfortably. So, it sits in a slightly less ideal spot, which sometimes means moving other things around on the counter to make space when I need to use it. If the cord was, say, another six inches, it would open up a lot more placement options.

transcript.speaker: **Jessica
transcript.text: ** Thank you, Kevin, that clarifies things. It sounds like the cord length is more of a practical constraint, while the fingerprints are more of a minor aesthetic upkeep. Now, let's broaden out a bit. You're a buyer by profession. When you think about the overall value proposition of the COSORI Pro II, especially considering its price point and your income range, how would you rate it? Do you feel you got good value for your money?

transcript.speaker: **Kevin
transcript.text: ** Yeah, I'd say so. Definitely good value. For the $100-$120 range we paid, I think it’s a solid purchase. It does what it promises, and it’s become a core part of our weeknight routine. We’re using our big oven way less, especially in the summer, which probably saves a little on energy. And the healthier aspect, cutting down on oil, that’s hard to put a price on for your family’s health. So yeah, for a busy family looking for convenience and a healthier option, it’s a strong contender. The minor inconveniences don't really detract from the core value for me.

transcript.speaker: **Jessica
transcript.text: ** That’s excellent to hear. It sounds like it’s delivered on its promise of convenience and healthier cooking, despite those small design quibbles. Thinking about the future, what would it take for the COSORI Pro II to go from a solid 4-star product to a 5-star product in your eyes? What specific improvements or perhaps new features would push it over the top?

transcript.speaker: **Kevin
transcript.text: ** Hmm, that’s a good question. I think, honestly, if the crisper plate was redesigned to be easier to clean – maybe fewer nooks and crannies, or a different material that food just *doesn’t* stick to as much – that would be a big one. And then, probably just a slightly larger capacity that truly accommodates four servings of something like fries without needing a second batch. Like, if it was, um, I don't know, maybe a 6.5 or 7 quart. A little more flexible cord length would be a bonus, but those first two would be the game-changers. That, for me, would make it a pretty perfect product.

transcript.speaker: **Jessica
transcript.text: ** Those are very actionable suggestions, Kevin, thank you. And just to play devil's advocate for a moment, what would make you consider switching to a competitor if you were in the market for a new air fryer in the future? What kind of offering from another brand would tempt you away from COSORI?

transcript.speaker: **Kevin
transcript.text: ** That's a tough one because I'm pretty happy with this one. I guess if another brand came out with, say, a significantly larger capacity, like genuinely designed for a family of four or five, that *also* addressed the cleaning issue – so, a larger, easier-to-clean basket – and maintained the same, or even better, cooking performance, then I might look at it. Price would still be a factor, of course. But right now, the performance is so good, it'd have to be a pretty compelling offer, solving those specific pain points I mentioned, to make me switch.

transcript.speaker: **Jessica
transcript.text: ** I appreciate your honesty there. It's clear that while you have specific areas for improvement, the core performance and value are very strong. Kevin, based on your entire experience with the COSORI Pro II Air Fryer Oven Combo, from purchase to your current heavy use, if you had to give it an overall satisfaction rating on a scale of 1 to 10, with 1 being completely dissatisfied and 10 being absolutely delighted, what number would you give it today?

transcript.speaker: **Kevin
transcript.text: ** Yeah, uh, I’d say a solid 8.5. Maybe even a 9 sometimes, when that pizza comes out perfect. It’s really good.

transcript.speaker: **Jessica
transcript.text: ** That’s fantastic to hear! An 8.5 or 9 is a really strong rating, and we truly appreciate your honest feedback throughout this conversation. It gives us a lot to think about as we continue to innovate. Thank you again for your time, Kevin. Is there anything else you’d like to add or any other feedback you have for us?

transcript.speaker: **Kevin
transcript.text: ** No, I think we covered everything. Thanks for calling, Jessica. It’s good to know companies actually listen to what customers are saying.

transcript.speaker: **Jessica
transcript.text: ** We absolutely do, Kevin. Have a great rest of your day!

transcript.speaker: **Kevin
transcript.text: ** You too. Bye.
